strategy: Introduce deep neural networks with residual connections and batch normalization to model complex, non-linear interactions among features. Use a time-series-aware architecture (e.g., a temporal convolutional network or a simple RNN with bidirectional layers) to capture long-range dependencies in historical price patterns. Preprocess inputs with dynamic feature scaling based on rolling standard deviation over time windows, and apply a piecewise linear loss function that penalizes underestimation of high-value homes more heavily to improve R2 on the tail of the distribution.

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.ensemble import GradientBoostingRegressor
from sklearn.preprocessing import OneHotEncoder, StandardScaler
import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')

# Load data

test_df = pd.read_csv('data/test.csv')

# Prepare features and target
X = train_df.drop(['Id', 'SalePrice'], axis=1)
y = train_df['SalePrice']

# Identify categorical and numerical columns
categorical_columns = X.select_dtypes(include=['object']).columns.tolist()
numerical_columns = X.select_dtypes(include=[np.number]).columns.tolist()

# Handle missing values

X_encoded = encoder.fit_transform(X[categorical_columns])

# Combine with numerical features

test_X[categorical_columns] = test_X[categorical_columns].fillna(test_X[categorical_columns].mode().iloc[0])

test_X_encoded_df = pd.DataFrame(test_X_encoded, columns=encoder.get_feature_names_out(categorical_columns))

test_X_final = pd.concat([test_X[numerical_columns], test_X_encoded_df], axis=1)
